arm_group.description: In addition to standard medical care and pharmacologic interventions, massage technique for 20 minutes for 5 to 14 days while in the ICU will be provided to help alleviate pain and anxiety in the patient.

Patients with an aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage will receive standard medical care to include pharmacologic interventions prescribed by the primary physician and nonpharmacologic interventions provided by the bedside RN such as ice or heat to address their pain and anxiety needs.

brief_summary.textblock:
This research study seeks to explore the effects of massage techniques on pain and anxiety
      relief among patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages in the ICU setting in comparison to
      subarachnoid hemorrhagic patients using standard medical therapy.

clinical_study.brief_title: Massage Technique for Pain, Anxiety and Delirium in SAH Patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Clinical diagnosis of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Upper extremity deep vein thrombus

          -  Active alcohol or drug withdrawal

intervention.description: Standardized massage technique aimed at the head, neck, and shoulders of patients with an aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage will be provided for 5 to 14 days while the patient is in the neuro ICU. The massage intervention will last approximately 20 minutes in the evening hours (from approximately 1900 - 2200).

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Massage Technique for Pain, Anxiety, and Delirium Management in ICU Patients With Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

primary_outcome.description: Over the course of the intervention period, the primary outcome of decrease in pain will be decreased as compared to the control group. This will be measured using the Pain Scale.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
